info.title: CRSS 4060/6060 Advc. Topics in Precision Ag. Bastos Material (UGA Spring 2023)

article.para: This is the welcome page for the 2023 CRSS 4060/6060 Advanced Topics in Precision Agriculture portion taught by Dr.Â Leo Bastos.

listitem.literallayout: CRSS 4060/6060 - Advanced Topics in Precision Agriculture
Spring Semester 2023
Athens campus: in person at 3203 Miller Plant Sciences
Tifton campus: in person at 601 NESPAL South OR remote

listitem.para: Griffin campus: M/F 217 SLC in person, W at 107 SLC in person OR remote

section.title: Prerequisites
section.para: CRSS 3030 â Principles of Precision Agriculture

section.title: Co-requisites
section.para: CRSS 4050 / 6050 â Improving Nutrient and Energy Efficiency with Geographic Information Systems or equivalent GIS course.

section.title: General information
section.literallayout: Dr.Â Leonardo M. Bastos, Assistant Professor Crop & Soil Sciences Dept. 4101 Miller Plant Sciences Building, Athens Campus University of Georgia Email: lmbastos@uga.edu URL: leombastos.github.io/bastoslab/

Dr.Â Lorena Lacerda, Assistant Professor Crop & Soil Sciences Dept. 4103 Miller Plant Sciences Building, Athens Campus University of Georgia Email: llacerda@uga.edu URL: https://cropsoil.uga.edu/people/faculty/lorena-lacerda.html

section.title: Office hours
section.para: Because of social distancing requirements, please make an appointment if you would like a face-to-face meeting with one of the instructors. Otherwise, we are always available by email.

section.title: Description
section.para: The course will emphasize sampling plan, obtaining and processing, and using various agricultural geospatial data layers for decision making related to precision agriculture. Data types used in the course include publicly available like weather, soils, and satellite remote sensing, and private data like yield monitor, Veris-derived soil electrical conductivity and elevation, and UAV remote sensing. Data processing steps include cleaning, removal of outliers, normalization, interpolation, and UAV imagery processing. Analytical techniques include clustering for creation of management zones, zone-based and imagery-based variable rate prescription, profitability maps, and use of satellite remote sensing for crop scouting. All steps will be conducted utilizing the R statistical language to create well documented and reproducible precision agriculture analytical workflows. No previous knowledge in R is required.

section.title: Course learning outcomes
section.para: Provide students with a good understanding of the emerging areas in precision agriculture, the ability to find, analyze and evaluate spatially distributed data sets, and the experience to use key precision agriculture tools and technologies. Additional goals are to:

listitem.literallayout: extend critical thinking and problem solving abilities
improve written and oral communication skills
learn how to create, present, and interpret maps

listitem.para: create reproducible analytical workflows using R

listitem.literallayout: Intro to R
Using R as a geographic information system (GIS)

listitem.para: Accessing publicly available geospatial data through R

Weather and satellite remote sensing from Google Earth Engine
State and county boundaries
Creating grids for soil sampling

Kriging
Understand the sources of error
Cleaning and removal of erroneous data points
Spatial and temporal yield variability analysis
Elevation
Aspect
Slope
Combining yield and soils data
Creating management zones with cluster analysis
Validating management zones
Data collection planning
Imagery processing
Zone-based variable rate prescription
Imagery-based variable rate prescription
Profitability maps
Satellite remote sensing for crop scouting
Undergraduate students: optional

section.title: Textbook
section.para: A textbook is not required. Reading materials will be supplied by instructor and will include benchmark research articles, manuals, and other materials.

section.title: Technology and software requirements
section.para: Students will need to have access to:

listitem.literallayout: A computer (to install software, code along with instructors)

listitem.para: A second screen (main screen to code along, second screen to watch class if not in person)

section.para: If a student does not have access to these resources (personal laptop/desktop and a second screen), please let instructors know to ensure proper accommodations can be made.

section.title: Course website
section.para: Important links related to this course:

section.title: Grading categories
section.para: The grade you receive in this course will be determined from your performance on a mini-project, one mid-term exam, periodic quizzes, homework assignments and lab reports, a team design project, a comprehensive final exam, and class participation. These factors will be weighted as follows:

entry.literallayout: Final project: from raw data to zone-based variable rate

section.title: Written assignment quality
section.para: Up to thirty percent of the grade on written assignments (mini-project, homework, final project) will be based on quality of communication.
Spelling, grammar, punctuation, and clarity of writing are evidence of written communication quality.

section.title: Class participation
section.para: Active class participation is important for you to achieve the learning goals of the class. To receive maximum credit for class participation you must

listitem.literallayout: attend every class period (lecture or laboratory)
arrive on time and remain for the entire class period
you are actively engaged and attentive throughout the class period

listitem.para: participate in the class discussion and ask and answer questions

section.title: Grading scale
section.para: Final grades will be assigned as follows:

section.title: Extra credit opportunities
section.para: Extra credit opportunities may be made available during projects, homework assignments, and exams, at the descrition of the instructors.

section.title: Academic honesty
section.para: UGA Student Honor Code: I will be academically honest in all of my academic work and will not tolerate academic dishonesty of others. A Culture of Honesty, the Universityâs policy and procedures for handling cases of suspected dishonesty, can be found at www.uga.edu/ovpi.
For this course, all lab reports, projects, and other assignments can be discussed with your classmates but any work you turn in must be your own.
Students can work together through coding exercises, but direct copying and pasting from a colleague will be considered plagiarism.
If using code from an online source, it is ok to copy and paste IF proper credit is given (e.g., showing the website source from where the code was obtained).
Unless explicitly stated, artificial intelligence-based technologies, such as ChatGPT, must not be used to generate responses for student assignments.

section.title: Attendance policy
section.para: Students are expected to attend every class period.

Students on the Athens campus must attend class in-person. If a special circumstance arise (illness, travel, etc.), student absence or remote attendance must be informed to instructors prior to that class period.

Students on the Tifton and Griffin campuses may attend class in-person on their campuses or remote using the zoom link information. Student absence must be informed to instructors prior to that class period.
Per Board of Regents policy, I reserve the right to drop students from the class roll who miss more than 5 class periods. Such students will be given a WF grade.

section.title: Disclaimer

listitem.literallayout: There will be no make-ups for missed quizzes. Any missed quiz will be recorded as a zero
Exams can be made up only with a note from a doctor or if you can document extenuating circumstances. Any unexcused missed exam will be recorded as a zero
Homework assignments will be accepted up to one week beyond the due date. The penalty for submitting a late assignment is one letter grade

listitem.para: Homework assignments may be submitted late without penalty in case of illness, extenuating circumstances, or if prior arrangements are made with the instructors. All late assignments are due within a week of the original due date or within a week of when a student returns from an illness

listitem.literallayout: If you or someone you know needs assistance, you are encouraged to contact Student Care and Outreach in the Division of Student Affairs at 706-542-7774 or visit https://sco.uga.edu/. They will help you navigate any difficult circumstances you may be facing by connecting you with the appropriate resources or services.
UGA has several resources for a student seeking mental health services (https://www.uhs.uga.edu/bewelluga/bewelluga) or crisis support (https://www.uhs.uga.edu/info/emergencies).

If you need help managing stress anxiety, relationships, etc., please visit BeWellUGA (https://www.uhs.uga.edu/bewelluga/bewelluga) for a list of FREE workshops, classes, mentoring, and health coaching led by licensed clinicians and health educators in the University Health Center.

listitem.para: Additional resources can be accessed through the UGA App.

section.title: Disability statement
section.para: If you plan to request accommodations for a disability, please register with the Disability Resource Center. They can be reached by visiting Clark Howell Hall, calling 706-542-8719 (voice) or 706-542-8778 (TTY), or by visiting https://sitedrc.uga.edu

section.title: Resources
section.para: Below there are some resources for students to further your knowledge in topics ranging from using quarto files, vector and raster manipulation in R, data visualization, and geostatistics.
